On October 1, 2010, the organization name for the Division Counsel (Large and Mid-Size Business) was changed to the Division Counsel (Large Business and International). In addition, Associate Area Counsels (Industry Program) were re-titled Deputy Area Counsels (Industry Program). CCDM subsections 33.3.4.1, 33.3.4.1.1, 33.3.4.2.1, 33.3.4.2.2, 33.3.4.2.3, 33.3.4.2.4, and 33.3.4.3 were
This supersedes CCDM 33.3.4 dated August 11, 2004.
Table of
33.3.4.3 Coordination with Industry and Issue Programs
(LB&I) Industry Program
page (

) These provisions outline the organization and operation of the Industry Program (IP) in the Office of Division Counsel (Large Business and Interna- tional) (LB&I), and describe the policy of providing informed, practical, and expedited legal support to the LB&I Pre-Filing and Technical Guidance program and Appeals. The Industry Program replaces the former Industry cialization Program. (
) The International Field Counsel Program in Division Counsel (LB&I) is not covered in these provisions and will be covered in a separate CCDM section. (

) Technical Advisors. Technical Advisors work within the Office of Pre-filing Technical Guidance (LB&I). They serve as nationwide experts in a particular industry or on a particular issue. They identify and develop significant issues, and other specifically designated issues, to ensure uniform and tent treatment of issues nationwide. (

) Deputy Area Counsel (Industry Programs). The Deputy Area Counsel (Industry Programs) provides primary support to the Area Counsel and Director staff with respect to industry specific pre-filing, filing, and post-filing activities. They oversee and supervise the Industry Counsel, who serve as primary Counsel liaison with the Technical Advisors aligned within their area’s respective industries or issues. (

) The Office of Chief Counsel provides the legal interpretation of the internal revenue laws. Industry Counsel play a critical role in fulfilling this for industry issues. They provide direct legal support to Technical Advisors, field examiners, appeals officers, and other field attorneys. They also coordination of industry issues with the Associate offices. (

) Industry Counsel are selected by the Area Counsel for the Area with bility for that particular industry or issue. To provide continuity and adequate support, more than one attorney may be designated as Industry Counsel, or Associate Industry Counsel, including additional attorneys from other Areas. (

) LB&I attorneys designated to provide support to Technical Advisors for an issue rather than for an industry are, for purposes of this subsection, consid- ered Industry Counsel to those Technical Advisors. They are often referred to as “Issue Counsel.” In general, the duties and responsibilities of Industry Counsel and Issue Counsel are identical. References in this section to “Industry Counsel” should be read to include Issue Counsel. (

) Industry Counsel develop a close working relationship with the Technical Advisors. They actively seek to identify and assist with the management of industry issues. They provide timely, informed, and practical advice on sub- stantive, procedural, and tactical questions. They work with the Technical Advisor to prepare material for team meetings, requests for published projects, requests for formal legal advice, and proposed Coordinated Issue Papers. They also work with Appeals in developing Appeals Settlement lines and Appeals Coordinated Issues. (

) Industry Counsel work with the Technical Advisor to maintain channels of munication and effective working relationships with industry groups, and their representatives. They attend periodic industry working sessions to discuss emerging issues, recent developments, and other matters of signifi- cance relating to the industry. Chief Counsel Directives Manual
Counsel (LB&I) Industry Program 33.3.4
The International Field Counsel Program in Division Counsel (LB&I) is not covered in these provisions and will be covered in a separate CCDM
33.3.4.1.1 (12-10-2010) Industry Counsel (Including Associate Industry Counsel)
Other Legal (

) Industry Counsel provide assistance nationwide to field attorneys, personnel and Appeals. They are familiar with the major industry cases. assist examination teams and field counsel advising the teams in obtaining other Counsel support in areas such as requesting legal advice, case ment, and issue coordination. They are aware of settlement trends on significant industry issues and provide advice as requested on settlement of specific cases. They take an active role in coordinating litigation affecting industry issues, and recommendations for designating industry issues for tion. They may participate in the trial of an industry issue, depending on workload and the significance of the issue. (

) Industry Counsel keep informed about significant industry issues that are consideration by Associate Chief Counsel offices. They comment on, and be included in, any guidance project relating to a significant industry issue. particular, Industry Counsel ensure that the Associate Chief Counsel offices have a full understanding of the industry background and potential ramifica- tions of such issues. (

) Industry Counsel are Division Counsel’s experts as to their assigned or issue. Industry Counsel gain knowledge of industry practices and issues. Priority is given to developing and sharing industry expertise through and internal training, subscribing to trade publications and attending industry meetings. (

) The Deputy Commissioner (International), the Industry Director, the Director, Pre-Filing & Technical Guidance, or Field Specialists may assemble Issue Teams, which may recommend coordination, administrative guidance, published legal guidance for emerging issues. In most instances, these will include Industry Counsel. (

) Industry projects and cases will occupy a substantial part of the Industry Counsel’s workload. Each Industry Counsel and supervisor will give industry assignments priority over other work assigned. Other work will be when necessary to accommodate this priority. (

) Associate Offices. An Associate Office, at the request of Division Counsel (LB&I), may appoint an attorney to be available for coordination of industry issues with the Industry Counsel and Technical Advisor. (

) Technical Advisors are responsible for developing coordination of key compliance issues. One tool used by Technical Advisors to ensure examination consistency in development and treatment of an issue is the Counsel dinated Issue Paper (CIP). The CIP is processed by the Director (Pre-Filing &Technical Guidance) and approved by an Associate Chief Counsel office. Issue After review and approval, the CIP is distributed to the field managers. (

) The CIP is submitted to the Director (Pre-Filing & Technical Guidance). The Director (PFTG) forwards the paper to the Division Counsel (LB&I) ters (attn: Special Counsel (PFTG)). Division Counsel (LB&I) controls and forwards the CIP to Technical Services Section (TSS) for assignment to the Associate Chief Counsel office with primary issue jurisdiction. To the extent possible, Division Counsel indicates the appropriate Associate office for ment. The Associate office has
days to review the CIP once received by TSS. The prime Branch is responsible for ensuring that all issues in the CIP Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.

The CIP is submitted to the Director (Pre-Filing & Technical Guidance). The Director (PFTG) forwards the paper to the Division Counsel (LB&I) headquar- ters (attn: Special Counsel (PFTG)). Division Counsel (LB&I) controls and forwards the CIP to Technical Services Section (TSS) for assignment to the Associate Chief Counsel office with primary issue jurisdiction. To the extent possible, Division Counsel indicates the appropriate Associate office for ment. The Associate office has

Counsel (LB&I) Industry Program 33.3.4

are properly coordinated with the Associate office(s) having jurisdiction over the relevant issue. These coordination efforts must be completed within the time allowed for review and the prime Branch issues one response that contains all Counsel comments on the proposed CIP. TSS runs a report of pending CIP assignments monthly. Copies of this report are furnished to Associate and Division Counsel (LB&I). (

) Initial Contact with LB&I. Within seven calendar days, the prime attorney should contact the Technical Advisor responsible for drafting the CIP and Division Counsel (LB&I) to inform them that the CIP is under review. (

) Request for Assistance from Other Associates. If the prime attorney fies issues that are outside the prime Associate office’s jurisdiction, an assistance request should be prepared within seven calendar days of assign- ment. Division Counsel (LB&I) should be notified of assistance requests. a. The prime attorney will send an assistance request, along with a WLI TECHMIS control sheet for the assistance WLI, to each office providing assistance. All relevant background material (e.g., draft CIP, prior legal advice) will be attached to each assistance request. It is the of the attorney to ensure that the WLI assistance information is entered into TECHMIS. b. The assistance request must state the date by which the prime attorney needs the response in order to respond within
days. Generally, the office providing assistance should have no less than

calendar days to respond. c. It is the prime attorney’s responsibility to follow up on all requests for as- sistance to ensure that the response is received in time to be into Counsel’s response. Late outstanding assistance requests should be promptly elevated to a Branch reviewer. (

) Scope of Review. In general, the Associate Chief Counsel reviews proposed CIPs for technical accuracy. Counsel will also evaluate and comment on the appropriateness of the CIP in light of factors such as pending or anticipated guidance or litigation activities. Counsel may approve the CIP as written or recommend changes. If Counsel concludes that the CIP has technical flaws, will state its reasons, outline the problems that need to be addressed and recommend solutions. a. The prime attorney is encouraged to work directly with the Technical Advisor and Industry Counsel informally (by telephone, email, fax, memoranda, or conference) to revise or supplement the CIP, as needed. The CIP remains assigned to the prime attorney pending the resolution any questions or suggested revisions. b. After completing the review (and receiving assistance, if any, from other Associate offices), the prime attorney prepares and forwards, through normal review channels, a final comment memorandum. The final comment memorandum will describe or include a version of the CIP that can be approved by Counsel without further substantive review. Alterna- tively, if the CIP cannot be revised to be legally correct or, if the issue addressed is inappropriate for a CIP, the final comment memorandum state that conclusion. For procedures regarding resolution of conflicting views, see IRM

, LB&I Coordinated Issues. c. If, at any time during its review of the CIP, the prime attorney briefs the Associate Chief Counsel relative to the CIP or its issue, the Director Chief Counsel Directives Manual

Scope of Review. In general, the Associate Chief Counsel reviews proposed CIPs for technical accuracy. Counsel will also evaluate and comment on the appropriateness of the CIP in light of factors such as pending or anticipated guidance or litigation activities. Counsel may approve the CIP as written or recommend changes. If Counsel concludes that the CIP has technical flaws, it will state its reasons, outline the problems that need to be addressed and recommend solutions.

a. The prime attorney is encouraged to work directly with the Technical Advisor and Industry Counsel informally (by telephone, email, fax, memoranda, or conference) to revise or supplement the CIP, as needed. The CIP remains assigned to the prime attorney pending the resolution of any questions or suggested revisions. b. After completing the review (and receiving assistance, if any, from other Associate offices), the prime attorney prepares and forwards, through normal review channels, a final comment memorandum. The final comment memorandum will describe or include a version of the CIP that can be approved by Counsel without further substantive review. Alterna- tively, if the CIP cannot be revised to be legally correct or, if the issue addressed is inappropriate for a CIP, the final comment memorandum will state that conclusion. For procedures regarding resolution of conflicting views, see IRM
, LB&I Coordinated Issues. c. If, at any time during its review of the CIP, the prime attorney briefs the Associate Chief Counsel relative to the CIP or its issue, the Director (Pre-
Filing & Technical Guidance) and Division Counsel (LB&I) will be of, and may be invited to participate in, the briefing. (

) Signature level and Case Closure. Counsel’s comment memorandum regarding the CIP is signed by the Associate Chief Counsel and the Division Counsel (LB&I), to the Director (PFTG). The CIP file should organized and submitted for closing and all TECHMIS assignments, all WLIs, should be closed. (
) The review of CIPs will be completed within
days of receipt and by TSS. The review is complete when the Associate Chief Counsel for Review Counsel’s final comment memorandum. If completion cannot occur within

days, the prime attorney will communicate the reasons for the delay, the expected completion date, directly to the Technical Advisor and the Counsel (LB&I), with information copies to the Associate Chief Counsel, Director (PFTG) and TSS. (

) The Special Counsel (Pre-Filing and Technical Guidance) in the Office of Division Counsel (LB&I) will be the primary contact to inquire about the Update of any proposed CIP which is under development or pending review in Counsel. (
) The authority to de-coordinate an issue rests solely with the (LB&I), generally based on advice from the Director (PFTG) and/or Director(s) in consultation with Division Counsel (LB&I). (
) Coordination with Industry Counsel is required whenever Counsel encounter issues in these areas. with (

Re- sponsibility for assuring appropriate coordination resides with the practice group Associate Area Counsel.
Counsel (LB&I) Industry Program 33.3.4

informally coordinate with the Industry Counsel via telephone and email to ensure that industry issues are developed and handled in a manner that promotes consistency and the proper legal outcome. Practice group will send to the Industry Counsel copies of their written advice (including messages) on industry issues. If there is a disagreement between the group attorney and Industry Counsel that cannot be resolved between them, they must elevate the issue to their respective managers for resolution. (

) When an Industry Counsel is contacted on an issue arising from a specific audit, the Industry Counsel must advise the Associate Area Counsel respon- sible for the audit location. When a taxpayer contacts an Associate Chief Counsel Office concerning a significant industry issue, the attorney in the Associate Office should notify the Industry or Issue Counsel. When an Counsel receives an inquiry directly from an audit team or field attorney, the Industry Counsel should coordinate with the Technical Advisor and Associate Chief Counsel, as appropriate. (

) Industry Counsel should coordinate with the appropriate Associate Chief Counsel Office to assure an issue reflects the correct interpretation of the law as applied to the facts of the particular case. The Industry Counsel should consult with the Technical Advisor concerning proposals for published that may affect industry issues.
